page.title: 04The Church
page.content:
Easton, so called because of its lying{east of Hingham,}which was the most important town in the area at one time, was owned by the manor of Costessey,{the Stafford family.
This was written about Easton: "This village is observed for its producing a man,{Adam de Easton}who was a{roman cardinal.}Adam de Easton was a benedictine monk in Norwich and a man of great wisdom and learning.
In{1381}he was made the Cardinal, {Dean of York}and because of this, his home of Easton became of new importance as did the benedictine abbey attached to Norwich cathedral. In spite of him being involved in a {plot against the Pope Urban in 1385}he was saved by powerful English influence.
